org.threadly.litesockets.utils

Class SSLProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.litesockets.utils.SSLProcessor

  • public class SSLProcessor
extends java.lang.Object
    This is a generic SSLClient that can be used to create an encrypted connection to a server. By default it will not check the servers certs and will only do TLS connections.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  SSLProcessor.EncryptionException
      Generic Exception to throw when we get an Encryption error.

    • Field Detail

      • EXTRA_BUFFER_AMOUNT

        public static final int EXTRA_BUFFER_AMOUNT
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PREALLOCATE_BUFFER_MULTIPLIER

        public static final int PREALLOCATE_BUFFER_MULTIPLIER
        This is how much extra buffer we allocate for read events so we do quite as much allocating. We always have to have at least 1 buffer the size SSLEngine says we need, but might use very little of it. This way we can allocate once and get multiple read events with it before we have to throw away allocated bytes an allocate more.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • handShakeStarted

        public boolean handShakeStarted()

      • isEncrypted

        public boolean isEncrypted()
        This lets you know if the connection is currently encrypted or not.
        Returns:
        true if the connection is encrypted false if not.

      • doHandShake

        public org.threadly.concurrent.future.ListenableFuture<javax.net.ssl.SSLSession> doHandShake()

        You can start the handshake by calling this method. If connect() has not been called on the client this will happen as soon as it is. The future allows you to know when the handshake has finished if if there was an error. While the handshake is processing all writes to the socket will queue.

        Returns:
        A ListenableFuture. If a result was given it succeeded, if there is an error it failed. The connection is closed on failures.
